item.description:
"A Franco-American Murder Mystery in Manchester: Lambert’s 'The Innocent Victim'"
Saturday, June 19, 2010
NEW LOCATION: At the Research Center - 129 Amherst Street
10:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m.
FREE Manchester Historic Association members; $10 general public
Pre-registration is requested.

The Civil-War era novel "The Innocent Victim" begins with a murder mystery in a downtown house in Manchester, and quickly draws the reader into a fast-paced tale of deceit, determination, lies, love, loss, and murder. Author Adélard Lambert, who lived in Manchester for many years, goes much further than the dramatic story of Jean and Marie Legendre and uses his novel to educate the reader about the experience of 19th century French-Canadian immigrants to New England. "The Innocent Victim" combines fiction and history in a story that is both entertaining and educational. Dr. Margaret S. Langford of Keene State College translated the book from French into English. She, and Manchester historian Robert B. Perreault, author of the book's foreword, will discuss Lambert's work. This book is available for purchase at the Museum Shop.
item.name: A Franco-American Murder Mystery in Manchester: Lambert's "The Innocent Victim"
